About

Hello! My name is Austin Choe and welcome to my coding portfolio. I am a new grad and ambitious worker looking for an entry job to start off my career and gain work experience!

I am skilled in Web Development (Front-End, Back-End, Full Stack) and I hope that this portfolio successfully showcases this. I am also skilled in Software Automation, Data Analysis, OOP, and more. I know languages like Java, JavaScript, C#, and Python.

Around the Web

...

.

AccuScrapper

Used Software Automation and Python to extract weather data from AccuWeather© and parsed this data organized into a comma separated value file. Used Restful API and libraries like Beautiful Soup and pandas to acquire data from multiple websites and sort them to a data frame that would then be exported to spreadsheet in the location of the user's choice.

Game of Life

2D Cellular Automation of Conway's Game of Life. Along with a data analysis on speedup and number of processes through parallel computation. This automation is coded in C++ and uses the library MPI for concurrent processing, partition of work, and communication among processes. This project uses standard and basic dependencies like ctime to detect the performance runtime and string/input/output streams. Also manipulates arrays with dimensional reshaping and flattening to accommodate MPI parameters.

Re-Audio

Application that allows user to modify exclusive process' volumes as well as manipulating Audio Endpoints such that output devices can be customized. This uses the console as a user interface that uses C-Sharp and .NET Framework integrated with an API called AudioSwitcher. This also uses System I/O to detect user input.

Raspberry Pi onto Xbox

In one of my extra-curriculars, me and my team had to implement the mechanics of a robot for a robotic competition. We used Java and Raspberry Pi to map out the controls from an Xbox Controller. This was a Research and Development experience as we were unfamiliar with robotics and the Application Programming Interface of a controller. We researched the API of the Xbox controller and how to map these mechanics to the motors we used for the physical abilities of the robot.

Color Segmentation using Gaussian Models

Created a program that automated the detection of a ball in an image input. Identified lower and upper bounds of HSV values and probability density function of both the Single Gaussian and Gaussian Mixure Models to determine if the pixel would reach the probability threshold that it contains the ball target. In regards to the GMM (Gaussian Mixture Model), we initialized the training images as well as the hyper parameters and used multiple gaussian influenced by scalars to identify new mean values, minimize misinterpretations or errors, and determine convergence. After the model has completed, we would create a pickle file to store these new parameters based on the training images.
